entry.title: Unexpected Costs Could Leave You Reeling
entry.content:
Donâ€™t go into a transaction unprepared. There is a difference between closing costs and the total cost to close, and it could be thousands of dollars.

Want to Sell Your Home? Get the Value of Your Central or Southwest Virginia Home
Looking to Buy a Home? Search All Homes on the MLS

Today weâ€™re going to discuss some of the unexpected costs you may run into when purchasing a home, specifically regarding closing costs.

Closing costs are different from the cost to close. A lot of people think closing costs are everything theyâ€™ll need to close on a home. 

The difference between specific closing costs and the total cost to close could be thousands of dollars.

In our area, however, closing costs are strictly defined in the contract, so the difference between specific closing costs and the total cost to close could be thousands of dollars. 

Your annual homeowners insurance is not a closing costâ€”it is a cost to close, as are property taxes. Things like that can run up your cost to close very quickly, so when youâ€™re getting a quote for closing costs, make sure itâ€™s not just for closing costs, but how much money you will actually need in total to be able to close on the home.


If you need any information about this or other topics, please feel free to contact us.

link.title: Unexpected Costs Could Leave You Reeling

entry.title: Do Speedy Visits Spell Disinterest for Your House?
entry.content:
If a buyer makes a speedy visit to your house, theyâ€™re probably not interested in it. Hereâ€™s why.

Want to Sell Your Home? Get the Value of Your Central or Southwest Virginia Home
Looking to Buy a Home? Search All Homes on the MLS


If a prospective buyer zips in and out of your house, theyâ€™re probably not a serious buyerâ€”at least not for your house.

There are a variety of reasons why a buyer would make a speedy visit. Maybe when they drove up to your home, they didnâ€™t like the landscaping, the exterior, or just the neighborhood in general. Perhaps when they walked into the house there was a smell or odor they didnâ€™t like. Maybe it just wasnâ€™t the right house for them.


A speedy visit means that buyer probably isnâ€™t interested in your house.


A serious buyer, on the other hand, will stop and envision themselves in your house. Theyâ€™ll take the time to imagine where their furniture would go and mentally pick out rooms for their children.

Itâ€™s very rare that a buyer zips in and out of your house and then comes back to make an offer on it. If they make a speedy visit, you pretty much have your answer whether theyâ€™re interested in your house or not.

If you have any questions about speedy visits or youâ€™re thinking of buying or selling a house in our Roanoke market, donâ€™t hesitate to reach out to us. Weâ€™d love to work with you.

link.title: Do Speedy Visits Spell Disinterest for Your House?

entry.title: What Type of Loans Exist for Renovations?
entry.content:
Are there any loan options for home renovations out there? There are two, but one is better than the other.

Want to Sell Your Home? Get the Value of Your Central or Southwest Virginia Home
Looking to Buy a Home? Search All Homes on the MLS


There are two types of loans that you can get to help fund your renovation project: the FHA loan and conventional loan.

The conventional loan is the more difficult of the two to get approved for. You need more money down than the other one, and we donâ€™t use that one very often for renovation projects.

The FHA 203K loan has two different options, depending on the size of your renovation project. Thereâ€™s a streamlined loan that is for repairs that are $30,000 or less and a full FHA 203k that is for as much as you need, as long as the house appraises as repaired.


On a full FHA loan, you can do whatever you would like to the home, as long as it appraises.


When you apply for the loan, you need to have two separate contractors come out to the house and write a bid for the repairs that they see that need to be done. These two bids need to matchâ€”not on the dollar amount but on what needs to be done to the home. Those bids are then sent to the lender so they can approach for the requested amount.

For the streamlined FHA loan, those repairs can only go up to $30,000 and canâ€™t be on anything structural, so no walls can be knocked out or rooms added. On a full FHA loan, you can do whatever you would like to the homeâ€”add or take out walls, add a new master bedroom or bathroomâ€”as long as the house appraises with those items included and itâ€™s under the lending limit, which in our area is $271,000.

If you have any questions about renovation loans, feel free to give me a call. Iâ€™d be happy to help you.

link.title: What Type of Loans Exist for Renovations?

entry.title: Do Open Houses Really Work?
entry.content:
There are a few things you need to know about open houses, and whether they are truly worth it.

Want to Sell Your Home? Get the Value of Your Central or Southwest Virginia Home
Looking to Buy a Home? Search All Homes on the MLS


A question my team and I often get is, â€œWhat happens when my agent meets a buyer at my open house?â€

The first thing to know is that nationally, less than 7% of open houses sell. In fact, the purpose of an open house is not typically to sell. The point is to acquire buyers.

To tell the truth, open houses donâ€™t work as well now as they used to for one simple reason: the internet. Most people find a large portion of their information about a given home online.

With things like the floor plan, 3D images, and videos available, physically visiting the home often doesnâ€™t come until the point where a buyer is fairly serious about making an offer.


Donâ€™t put too much stock in the buyers who
show up to an open house.


But where they lack in successful selling power, open houses are still effective in attracting buyers.

Along with those buyers, though, an open house can also draw out a lot of nosy neighbors.

So if your agent does do an open house, donâ€™t put too much stock in the buyers who show up there.

If you have any other questions or would like more information, feel free to give me a call or send me an email. I look forward to hearing from you soon.

entry.title: Should You Bring an Architect in on a Home Inspection?
entry.content:
Can you bring an architect or engineer with you to a home inspection? When should you do that?

Want to Sell Your Home? Get the Value of Your Central or Southwest Virginia Home
Looking to Buy a Home? Search All Homes on the MLS


Lately, a lot of homebuyers have asked me, â€œCan I bring an architect or engineer with me on a home inspection? Should I make the house purchase subject to an architectural review or have an engineer look at it?â€

If you really want to talk to an engineer or architect, the only way you can ask is to write it into the contract. Make the offer subject to an architect or engineer reviewing the home plans. Your agent will help you with the exact language.

If you plan on doing a huge remodel, itâ€™s a good idea to bring in an engineer.


You donâ€™t always need an engineer to look at a home before you buy it. If you are buying a house and you want to blow out the walls and open up the floor plan, then it would be a good idea to have an architect or engineer check the property. They will let you know which walls are load-bearing, and then you can make an educated buying decision.

The worst thing you can do is buy a house, blow out the wrong wall, and have the house implode on you.

What does it mean when someone says they are â€œjust startingâ€ their home search? Well, it can mean a lot of things. Your home may actually be the first home they have looked at, or it could be the 50th. Thereâ€™s a better way to tell if a buyer is serious about buying a home or not.

If the buyer you talk to is pre-approved for a mortgage and working with a real estate agent, I would take them very seriously. They could give you your highest offer and if nothing else, they will give you good feedback about your home so you can improve it for the next buyer who comes through.

entry.title: Is the Home Inspector Really Working for You?
entry.content:
Do home inspectors work for the buyer or the seller? The answer really depends on one simple thing.

Want to Sell Your Home? Get the Value of Your Central or Southwest Virginia Home
Looking to Buy a Home? Search All Homes on the MLS

Who does the home inspector work for, the homebuyer or the seller? 

The answer is really very simple. The home inspector works for whoever pays them. 

So, if you negotiate for the seller to pay for the home inspection, then the home inspector will work for the seller and look out for their needs. It all boils down to who writes the check for the home inspector. 

When you buy a home, I highly recommend that you hire the home inspector, radon inspector, water test company, and termite inspector. After all, once you own the home, you are responsible for any issues.

Pay extra attention to the termite inspection.

You should pay extra attention to the termite inspection. Remember, not all termite inspectors are created equal. If you buy a house, do you want any termite inspector or the best termite inspector? We recommend Brad Killinger from Killinger Pest Inspections. He is an honest inspector, which is exactly what you want: someone who will honestly tell you about any problems in the home. 

If you need any recommendations for other home inspections or if you have any real estate questions, just give me a call or send me an email. I would be happy to help you!

entry.title: How Does Refreshing Your Linens Help Sell Your Home?

If you are thinking of selling your home, I recommend that you refresh your linens. Why? 

The simple reason is that old linens do not show well. If you have an old, worn bedspread that has a burned spot from an old ironing accident, buyers will think that you canâ€™t take care of your home. 

In fact, I walked into a house the other day where the drapes matched the wallpaper, which matched the bedspread, which matched the throw rugs. The entire room looked like one big ivy vine because every surface was covered with the same print.

You need to have classy, fresh linens in your home.

You need to have classy, clean, fresh linens in your home. If you donâ€™t want to get rid of your old, comfortable bedspread, simply put the new one on top of it when you prepare to sell your home. Doing so will position your house to sell faster and for more money. 

You want people to feel like they could live in your house. They need to be comfortable in your house and every room needs to be fresh and clean.

entry.title: What Do You Actually Get from a Home Inspection?
entry.content:
Not many home buyers seem to truly understand what you get with a home inspection, so today, I wanted to clarify the possible outcomes of such inspections.

Want to Sell Your Home? Get the Value of Your Central or Southwest Virginia Home
Looking to Buy a Home? Search All Homes on the MLS

When it comes to home inspections, one of the most common misconceptions is that they cover only a basic inspection. 

Home inspections are designed to give you a report card on your house. In the grand scheme of things, it outlines everything a home inspector can find during a three- to four-hour window. They won't find everything, but they will find more than just the basics.

An inspector will look at the systems, appliances, and HVAC, to name a few. Their job is to give you a good report card of your house, because not all these items will be covered by the contract, and not all these things will be repaired by the contract. Instead, you'll get a good list of things to work on in the house. Remember, when you buy a house, you buy a used house; it's going to have issues.

The inspector's job is to give you a good report card of your house.

The good news is that you'll get a really good report up front to know what's wrong with it.

If you have any questions about home inspections and what you get from them, or you're ready to buy or sell a home in the Roanoke market, give me a call or send me an email. I'd be happy to help!

entry.title: What Should You Look for in a Home Inspection?

When people ask us about home inspections, they usually want to know two things:

  1. What does an inspector look for in a home inspection?
  2. What can I ask for in a home inspection?

As to what you can ask for in a home inspection, in our contract, a home inspection limits you to asking for material defects. A material defect is defined as â€œsomething that wouldâ€™ve caused a normal buyer not to purchase the home had they known it was there.â€.

Home inspections are there to investigate any major issues in the house.

What an inspector looks for during a home inspection is major issues within the house. Theyâ€™re not looking for any cosmetic issues such as the paint or the wall coverings. If youâ€™re worried about those types of issues, they should be taken care of in the contract. During a home inspection, the key is to look for issues like a leaky roof, any type of plumbing system or electrical setup thatâ€™s not safe and functional, and any overarching structural issues.

entry.title: What Can Landscaping Do for the Value of Your Property?

You need to invest in your home to get it sold for top dollar.

entry.title: What You Need to Know About Inspections
entry.content:
If you're buying a home at any point, you'll have to deal with a home inspection. So who chooses the inspector? What do they look for? How do you know if they're right for you?

Want to Sell Your Home? Get the Value of Your Central or Southwest Virginia Home
Looking to Buy a Home? Search All Homes on the MLS

There are some important things you need to know about a home inspection. If you've ever bought or sold a home or you plan on buying a home at any point in the future, you'll deal with an inspector at some point. 

So who chooses the home inspector? It's simpleâ€“you do. I highly suggest that before choosing one, you call them and ask them some questions. You want to ask what they will check, whether they will actually get on your roof and check it, whether they have a septic or sewer camera, whether they do thermal imaging, etc. You need to ask them whether they will look at something you're concerned about; don't just assume they'll do it.

Don't just assume they'll inspect everything you're worried about.

Not all home inspectors are created equal, just like not all real estate agents are created equal. Since it's your right to pick your home inspector, you need to pick the one that's right for you.

entry.title: Real Estate Agents vs. Realtors
entry.content:
Many people have asked me, â€œWhat is a Realtor?â€ 

In order to sell properties in the state of Virginia, you need to be a licensed real estate agent. Realtor is a professional designation saying that the real estate agent belongs to the National Association of Realtors and subscribes to a code of ethics.

The code of ethics was put in place to protect the public and other licensed real estate agents. Itâ€™s a set of rules that define how we treat the public and other real estate agents. Basically, we promise to treat you ethically, honestly, and morally.
A Realtor will treat you ethically, honestly, and morally.
Again, if a real estate agent is a Realtor, that doesnâ€™t mean they have a special license. That just means that they are a licensed real estate agent who belongs to the NAR and subscribes to the code of ethics.

If you have any questions about Realtors, how to become a Realtor, or anything else about real estate, please donâ€™t hesitate to give me a call or send me an email. I would be happy to help you!

How do you pick the right lender?

When youâ€™re looking for a lender, you want to ask your real estate agent two things: who do they know and who do they trust? Real estate agents donâ€™t make any more or less based on which lender you use. The only difference is whether or not itâ€™s going to make their lives any easier. When you use a lender that your agent knows and trusts, they usually get a property to close faster and with less hassle. If it makes their life easier, odds are itâ€™s going to make your life easier too.

No one wants to deal with an out-of-towner.

No one wants to deal with an out-of-town lender. They have neither a viable reputation nor a stake in this town. If they mess up a loan, it doesnâ€™t affect them long-term at all. Local lenders, on the other hand, live where we live, eat where we eat, and socialize where we socialize. Our community is their community. They canâ€™t afford to mess up loans. They canâ€™t afford for your house to close 30 days late because they didnâ€™t do their job.

You need someone on your side.

Neighbors are one demographic of people that do frequently attend open houses. Neighbors may want a friend or family member to buy a house near them, so they decide to do a little legwork and check out the open house.

As a buyer, when you attend an open house, bring your buyerâ€™s agent with you. If they arenâ€™t able to be with you, tell the seller and their agent that you are working with one. We did that because I donâ€™t like before/after photos - the lighting is different, the house is different, the cameraâ€™s different, even the location is different. We tell sellers all the time that the first thing people do when they decide to sell a car is detail it. The logic is no different with selling a house. Box up all the things you
donâ€™t need and store them elsewhere.

Therefore, box up everything that you donâ€™t need and ship it out. If itâ€™s spring or summer, get rid of all your winter clothes. If the kids have toys they donâ€™t play with anymore, they go too. If you canâ€™t afford to rent a storage unit or a pod to store it all, thatâ€™s fine. Just use your garage or basement. entry.title: Finding Your Roanoke Homeâ€™s Value With a Market Analysis
entry.content:
Buying a Central or Southwest Virginia Area home? Perform a full home search
Selling your Central or Southwest Virginia Area home? Get a free Home Price Evaluation

What is a market analysis (or CMA - comparative market analysis)? A CMA is a synopsis of whatâ€™s going on in the market for a comparable house with comparable features to yours.

What a CMA does is search in parameters - usually the same grade school area (the smallest searchable area), because people tend to want to stay in the same school district that their kids attend. In that area, it searches for houses of the same square footage, bedrooms, bathrooms, and features. It takes that information, enters it into a graph, and starts adjusting value according to each houseâ€™s variables. If, for example, one house has a pool and another house doesnâ€™t, there would be an adjustment.
â€œ
A market analysis analyzes the market
to determine your homeâ€™s actual value

â€
We do whatâ€™s called an "equity valuation". We use Zillow reports, tax tickets, Realtor.com, and the MLS to make a comprehensive report to show you what the house is worth. When youâ€™re trying to sell a house, thatâ€™s what youâ€™re trying to find out - the actual value of your house. A lot of people want to list it over that value, but this doesnâ€™t really work because whoever is buying the house has also done a CMA. Weâ€™re all dealing with the same set of numbers.

Believe it or not, appraisers actually get their numbers from the MLS. When we have a price that seems out of line, theyâ€™ll call us and ask what comps (comparable sales) we used.

If you have any more questions about a CMA, feel free to reach out by phone or email and Iâ€™d be happy to explain it to you.

link.title: Finding Your Roanoke Homeâ€™s Value With a Market Analysis

entry.title: Can You Really Make Money By Timing the Market in Roanoke?
entry.content:
Buying a Central or Southwest Virginia Area home? Perform a full home search
Selling your Central or Southwest Virginia Area home? Get a free Home Price Evaluation

Do you know when the right time is to put your home on the market in Roanoke? Every Realtor will tell you now is a great time, but truly, any time is a good time. 

Everybody is worried about timing the market, just like people in stocks worry about timing the market. Any investment counselor will tell you not to time the market, but to just be consistent. On the real estate side, people want to time the market so they can get the absolute most for their house, but that typically means they're also going to pay the absolute most for their next house. That's why timing in the market has always confused me. 
â€œ
You're really not going to lose money either way.

â€
What I tell my clients is that if you're ready to sell, let's sell your house. If you're not ready, let's not sell. If it's giving you anxiety and you're not ready, there's no point in pushing it. On the other hand, if it's a burning desire in your heart, or you need to move for reasons like marriage or a job transfer, you're going to sell high and typically turn around and buy high, and vice versa. It averages out, so as long as you have a Realtor that's going to represent your best interests and make sure you don't make a mistake, then you're really not going to lose money either way. 

If you have any questions, feel free to give me a call or send me an email. I look forward to continuing the conversation.

Additionally, if you're having a home built, I strongly recommend a pre-drywall inspection. It's one of the best inspections because the inspector sees inside the house before the drywall is up. They can see the plumbing, electrical, and gas systems. Many home inspectors will do a "two stage" home inspection; one before drywall, and another after completion. 

When building, think about radon, since itâ€™s unfortunately common in our area. It's easy to put a clean and attractive passive radon system in a house for less than $150 when it's being built. After it's built and it has radon, it becomes much more expensive. Avoid the extra expenses by preparing ahead of time!

Hopefully, youâ€™ve done your homework. You should be pre-approved already or have a letter showing you have cash to purchase the home. Once thatâ€™s resolved, your agent will give a copy of the contract to the lender and the title company. 

We will also contact a home inspector. You will need a home inspection and a radon inspection on the property. After that, you will sit down with your agent and go through the inspection report to determine necessary repairs.


Every house has issues - thatâ€™s just part of the joy of homeownership. When you go through an inspection report, look for major issues, especially things that might have prevented you from making an offer in the first place. Donâ€™t worry about minor problems. 

You will ask the seller to fix any major repairs, and then youâ€™re back in negotiations. You negotiate with the seller on what they will or will not fix. 

After that, itâ€™s pretty smooth sailing through the closing table. Just make sure you get all your paperwork in on time so that you arenâ€™t responsible for delaying the closing process.

In our market, itâ€™s not too hard to tell whether we have the right price for your home. entry.title: What Must You Disclose to a Buyer?
entry.content:
Buying a Central or Southwest Virginia Area home?  Perform a full home search
Selling your Central or Southwest Virginia Area home?   Get a free Home Price Evaluation

We recently got a question from a client that we decided to answer today. The question was â€œWhat is my obligation to disclose?â€, which can be a confusing subject during the course of a home sale.

In Virginia, we are a disclosure/disclaimer state, but everybody disclaims. A disclaimer simply states that you do not know of anything wrong with the house. You donâ€™t have to disclose anything as a seller, but you canâ€™t conceal anything either. If you know the basement leaks and pile up things so itâ€™s hidden, then you could get in trouble.


As an agent, I am required to disclose anything that I know about the home. That means if I find a leak, or a foundation issue, I have to disclose it. 

If you really donâ€™t want the buyer to know about something, then you should not tell your agent. Once they know there is an issue, they are required by law to disclose it. This is why we recommend a home inspection before you list, so you can be aware of any issues right off the bat, and then you have nothing to hide.

If you have any questions for us, feel free to give us a call or send us an email. We look forward to speaking with you!

entry.title: The Best Time to Sell a Central or Southwest Virginia Home
entry.content:
Buying a Central or Southwest Virginia Area home?  Perform a full home search
Selling your Central or Southwest Virginia Area home?   Get a free Home Price Evaluation

People constantly ask me when the best time to sell a home is. To be honest, the best time to sell is when you have a buyer that's ready, willing, and able to meet your terms.

For a technical answer, the spring time is the default selling season. A lot of people are buying homes, but a lot of people are also selling homes at that time. This means that if you sell in the spring you'll face more competition, but there will also be more buyers, so it's a bit of a double-edged sword.

To be honest, we probably sell more homes in the winter than any other season. Competition is low, and the people who purchase in winter are often much more serious about buying a home. Nobody walks out into the cold to just browse homes. The home buyers in the winter are very serious about purchasing.


Overall, people purchase homes year-round. It sounds cliche, but it's always a good time to sell a home. It's just a matter of examining your particular situation and finding a buyer willing to pay top dollar.

If you have any further questions about buying or selling in Roanoke, please don't hesitate to contact me!

entry.title: Why Is Radon So Dangerous?
entry.content:
Buying a Central or Southwest Virginia Area home?
Perform a full home search

Selling your Central or Southwest Virginia Area home?
 Get a free Home Price Evaluation

Many people ask me, "What is radon?" Radon is actually a gas that is emitted from rock formations under the earth and can be dangerous to humans.

This area actually has a lot of radon. More than half of our houses have what the EPA calls unacceptable levels of radon in the home. The EPA says that 3.9 is the highest acceptable level for radon. If you test your home and the radon test comes in at 4.0, you have failed the test and if you're in the middle of a real estate transaction, that transaction will fall through.

Now, a house could pass the test this year and fail next year. Depending on the weather, the house could pass one week and then fail the next week due to rainfall.

I highly suggest that every house gets tested. If you have radon, you can put a mitigation system in. The mitigation system dries out your basement and ventilates the gas out of your home.

The reason you don't want radon in your house is that radon is the second leading cause of cancer deaths. What happens is radon carries an atom that explodes in your lungs and shreds them. If you don't smoke, your lungs could heal. If you do smoke, the tar in your lungs prevents your lungs from healing.

Although the EPA says that 4.0 is an unacceptable radon level, I would say that your levels are above 3.0, go ahead and mitigate your home just to be safe.

If you have any questions for me, give me a call or send me an email. I would be happy to help you.

Our average client looks at 7-10 homes and they are all homes that match their criteria and that they want to see. Itâ€™s a really good, simple way to ensure you wonâ€™t waste your time looking at homes you donâ€™t want to see, and it will be a good use of your time.

entry.title: Potential Problems to Look Out for During Your Home Search
entry.content:
Buying a Central or Southwest Virginia Area home? 
Perform a full home search

Selling your Central or Southwest Virginia Area home? 
 Get a free Home Price Evaluation

Today, we're going to talk about what you should look for when you're looking at a home. First of all, you don't ever want to have to convince yourself to buy a home. When you walk into the right home, you're going to know it.
That said, you do want to pay attention to anything that would cause you not to buy the house. Every house will probably have settlement cracks, but settlement cracks that are larger on one end than the other are actually spreading. Split bricks could also be an indication of a foundation problem.
You always want to look at chimneys for water issues. Also pay attention to skylights and windows.


The yard should slope away from the house; otherwise, water will be moving towards your home.
We always suggest you get a home inspection by a good home inspector. We recommend Blue Ridge home inspection. We also suggest getting a home warranty. This is like a service plan on the house. You do pay a deductible, but if the HVAC or water heater goes out, then you're covered. We recommend checking out Home Warranty of America.
If you have any questions about this or any other real estate topic, please don't hesitate to contact us. I would love to hear from you!

link.title: Potential Problems to Look Out for During Your Home Search

We use Joel Balsley with Atlantic Bay Mortgage. He's a very honest lender who's going to tell you exactly what you need to do to purchase a home. Most Realtors in our area prefer a local lender because they're easier to reach. I wouldn't advise using an online mortgage lender - they often make it more difficult to purchase a home. We like to be able to communicate easily with our lenders and find that this makes the home buying process much easier.



Once you know how much you can afford you can narrow down your home search. We don't want you to fall in love with a home, only to find out that you can't buy it because you can't afford it.
If you have any questions or if you'd like to contact Joel, please don't hesitate to reach out to us. We look forward to hearing from you!

entry.title: What's Wrong with FSBO Properties?
entry.content:
Buying a Central or Southwest Virginia Area home? 
Perform a full home search

Selling your Central or Southwest Virginia Area home? 
 Get a free Home Price Evaluation


I personally commend anyone who wants to try and sell their home on their own. It's a lot of work and it requires a lot of time, so hats off to you if you have been successful in doing so.

With this being said, we actually end up selling quite a few For Sale by Owner (FSBO) properties. We sell these successfully, and the homeowners usually walk away happy.

The thing with FSBO sales is that they're usually done because the owner wants to make the highest amount possible when selling. However, people realize that FSBO properties don't have to pay commission to real estate agents, and because of this, they often make low ball offers on these properties. On the flip side, FSBO sellers often overprice their homes because they want to get the most money out of a sale as possible.

This often causes FSBO properties to sit on the market for a long time, and when this happens, people begin to believe that something is wrong with the home. This causes the home to go stale, and the sellers end up with a much smaller amount of money than they thought they would be getting.
 
It's a fact (proven by the NAR) that homes that are sold by real estate agents will often sell faster and for more money than a FSBO seller. Real estate agents have superior marketing capabilities, and they also know how to price homes attractively in order to bring in the right type of buyers.

We always suggest that you use a real estate agent, especially if you're planning on making a profit off of your home sale. Please don't hesitate to contact our team if you'd like to sell for top dollar in Roanoke.

entry.title: Watch Out for Zillow
entry.content:
Buying a Central or Southwest Virginia Area home? 
Perform a full home search

Selling your Central or Southwest Virginia Area home? 
 Get a free Home Price Evaluation

Today I'd like to speak about Zillow. A lot of people who are looking to buy or sell homes are turning to this site as a major resource. This website aggregates a lot of data from tax records and previous home sales, but it is usually not updated or very accurate.
 
The problem is that Zillow doesn't know neighborhoods, and it doesn't take into account HOA associations or the quality of school districts. Zillow Zestimates are wildly inaccurate, a fact that they do not deny. While Zillow may be a useful tool to help point you in a certain direction, you should not be using it to guide yourself through real estate transactions.

If you want a truly valuable resource, then I suggest simply contacting your local real estate agent. Your local agent can pull comparable values for your property, and they have their feet on the ground so they have the wherewithal to tell you what is actually happening in the real estate market.

If you need any assistance when you're buying or selling, please don't hesitate to contact me. I would be more than happy to help you out.

entry.title: What You Should Know About Appraisals
entry.content:
Buying a Central or Southwest Virginia Area home? 
Perform a full home search

Selling your Central or Southwest Virginia Area home? 
 Get a free Home Price Evaluation

Today I want to explain the appraisal process to you and explain it in detail. It means different things for buyers and sellers, and you should know the difference.

For starters, an appraisal is usually carried out by the bank to ensure that the home is priced properly. All that an appraiser really looks at is the square footage, the number of bedrooms, the construction style, and the age of the home.

Any part of your home that is underground will not be taken into account for square footage, so we sometimes have difficulty appraising split level homes that have finished spaces below ground.

Appraisals are extremely important to the selling process because if an appraiser's valuation doesn't match the asking price, the sale can be ruined.
 
If you have any more questions about appraisals and how they can impact your buying and selling process, please don't hesitate to contact me.

link.title: What You Should Know About Appraisals

entry.title: When Is the Best Time to Renovate Your Home?
entry.content:
Buying a Central or Southwest Virginia Area home? 
Perform a full home search

Selling your Central or Southwest Virginia Area home? 
 Get a free Home Price Evaluation

People commonly ask me about home renovations and if they will increase the value of their home. They also ask me about the best point in time to do a renovation on their home.
 
Contrary to popular belief, putting money into repairs and renovations on your home right before you sell it is not the best time to do so. The NAR has done a lot of research on this, and their data shows that most repairs and renovations will not get you a dollar for dollar return on a home. In fact, most repairs will not net you any extra money in a home sale.

In my opinion, the best time to renovate is right after you've moved into a home. That way, you can enjoy the repairs that you've made. It's best to do renovations as you live in your home because you will inevitably have to do them when you move out.

Buyers really dislike wallpaper right now, and if your home is worth more than $250K, you will probably have to install granite countertops if you want to sell for top dollar. Outdated carpet or parquet floors are also things that you should change if they're in your home right now.

If you have any other questions about renovations, please don't hesitate to contact me.

link.title: When Is the Best Time to Renovate Your Home?

entry.title: How Can You Win a Multiple Offer Situation?
entry.content:
Buying a Central or Southwest Virginia Area home? 
Perform a full home search

Selling your Central or Southwest Virginia Area home? 
 Get a free Home Price Evaluation

The central and southwest Virgina real estate market has been very active as of late, so today we want to explain how to deal with multiple offer situations!

The easiest way for you to win a multiple offer situation is to be prepared. To get ready for the buying process, you need to talk to a local lender and get pre-qualified. If you're using a local lender, while other buyers are using an online lender (or aren't even qualified), you're already well on your way to getting your offer accepted.

If you want to stand out in a crowded market, you need to submit a clean offer. Complicated offers with a lot of stipulations and contingencies are not very attractive to sellers. They don't want to accept an offer that has a lot of interference and difficulty in getting closed.
 
If you have further questions on this topic, or if you need real estate assistance of any kind, don't hesitate to reach out to us. We would love to hear from you!

entry.title: How Do Rent-Back Agreements Benefit Buyers and Sellers Alike?
entry.content:
Buying a Central or Southwest Virginia Area home? 
Perform a full home search
Selling your Central or Southwest Virginia Area home? 
 Get a free Home Price Evaluation

A lot of people ask whether a buyer can charge the seller if they choose to remain in the home after closing. Today, we answer this question for you!

The answer isn't a straight yes or no. In real estate, everything is negotiable. A lot of times, the seller has a reason they need to stay in the house until closing: the next house isn't ready, they're trying to finish up a job, the kids are still in school, etc. To solve this problem, a common solution is what's called a rent-back agreement. This means the seller can actually rent the house back for a predetermined amount of time after closing.

If you're selling and you want to rent-back, you need to negotiate it before the contract is written! Negotiating a rent-back agreement up front will usually result in an agreement between the buyer and seller, with few problems. The amount that's charged in a rent-back situation will depend on how negotiations go, but typically, you'll be paying what the buyer's mortgage payments would be.

If you have any questions about this process, or if you need real estate assistance of any kind, give us a call or shoot us a quick email. We would love to hear from you!

link.title: How Do Rent-Back Agreements Benefit Buyers and Sellers Alike?

entry.title: Is the Central and Southwest Virginia Market About to Shift?
entry.content:
Buying a Central or Southwest Virginia Area home? 
Perform a full home search
Selling your Central or Southwest Virginia Area home? 
Get a free Home Price Evaluation

There is a lot of concern in the Central and Southwest Virginia areas right now. Norfolk Southern is leaving for Atlanta, which will result in the loss of a significant number of jobs. In July, the post office is also closing, which will only add to the number of jobs lost in our area.

I have friends and clients who are trying to "time" the market: they want to wait until a bunch of homes hit the market so they can find a deal. The problem with doing this is it's like timing the stock market. Any expert will tell you it's futile to try to time the market; you need to buy stock consistently over time before it will do you any good. The same logic applies to purchasing property: timing the market is futile.

All we know is that interest rates are low NOW. There's no knowing what's going to happen when Norfolk Southern leaves town. It's been rumored that they're not offering very good incentives for employees to move with them, so there's a chance there won't even be that many homes on the market once they leave. There's a good chance the market won't react the way many think it will, and prices won't drop substantially if they drop at all. We're not sure this is going to happen, but it's likely, and would be good for the market and the economy if it does.

If you have any questions about our changing area, or if you need real estate assistance of any kind, give me a call or shoot me an email. I would love to hear from you!

Also, if you're interested in what's going in our marketplace, check out our new website. There are a lot of neat features the other website didn't have, and we think you'll enjoy it!

link.title: Is the Central and Southwest Virginia Market About to Shift?

entry.title: Roanoke Real Estate Market Update for Fall 2014
entry.content:
There are many great Lynchburg, Roanoke and New River Valley homes for sale. Click here to perform a full home search, or if you're thinking of selling your home, click here for a FREE Home Price Evaluation so you know what buyers will pay for your home in today's market. You may also call me at (540) 278-1401 for a FREE home buying or selling consultation to answer any of your real estate questions.

Roanoke Real Estate Market Update for Fall 2014

Thanks for visiting our blog again! Today we are going to talk to you about the latest happenings in the Roanoke real estate market. In Central and Southwest Virginia, we are seeing a bit of a slowdown. It's becoming more of a buyer's market right now. Absorption rates are a little bit higher than they have been and we are just a bit slower than we were at  this point last year.

With the market slowing down, anyone looking to sell needs to find an agent that can expose their house properly in every avenue. They need to know how to use internet marketing as well as how to properly stage and show a house. Most importantly, your agent needs to know how to price your home properly. If they don't, it will just sit there on the market, stagnant.

One thing that our agents are trained to do is an equity evaluation, where we take into account many different criteria that help us determine what the market in your area is truly like and it gives you a great picture of what your home may be worth in the future.

Interest rates are dipping again. They had gotten up to the mid 4%'s but recently we have seen them as low as 3.8%, which is an extremely low rate. If you're on the fence about whether you should move into a new home or not, as long as you have a stable job, now is the time to really get out there and do this. At some point, feds will stop bailing out the economy and the rates will probably go up to normal levels around 6 or 7%.

If you have any questions, please give us a call or send us an email. We will reach out to you and see what we can do to help you!

entry.title: The Pros and Cons of the Zillow/Trulia Merger
entry.content:
There are many great Lynchburg, Roanoke and New River Valley homes for sale. Click here to perform a full home search, or if you're thinking of selling your home, click here for a FREE Home Price Evaluation so you know what buyers will pay for your home in today's market. You may also call me at (540) 278-1401 for a FREE home buying or selling consultation to answer any of your real estate questions.

The Pros and Cons of the Zillow/Trulia Merger

If you have been following the news recently, you may have noticed that internet home search giant Zillow has announced that they have purchased their top competitor, Trulia. What does this mean for you and your home search? We are here to answer the question. A lot of people have been discussing the buyout and we are hearing a lot of pros and a lot of cons.

Basically, you have 2 sites here that are owned outside of the real estate industry. Their data is still being gathered by 3rd and 4th parties and isn't near as accurate as that data that a real estate agent can provide you.

Realtors have access to the MLS and sold data. They are local professionals, whereas Zillow and Trulia don't know specific markets. These sites are good at assimilating information by not necessarily good at deciphering it and explaining it to the customer.

A lot of people want to be able to go online and find a source that will do everything for them. But the truth is, your big purchases and large financial investments are important, and it pays to use someone local who knows what they are doing, especially in your area. You want to use people that are responsible and liable so that when decisions are made, they are made by individuals who understand everything about the market in your specific area. You can't make those kinds of decisions in the internet.


If you have any questions about the Zillow/Trulia merger or anything about real estate in general, give us a call or send us an e-mail. We would be happy to answer any question you may have.

link.title: The Pros and Cons of the Zillow/Trulia Merger

Today I wanted to speak with you about why it is important for a seller to accurately price their home from the beginning. Before I begin, I wanted to point out that our blog features an MLS search feature that allows you to search for homes at any time and a free market value report that allows you to obtain the value of your home at any time.
     
What Happens When You Price Your Home Too High

Unfortunately when you price your home too high the market first rejects your price, you donâ€™t get any activity in your house and when you finally implement price reductions, people over look your home because it has sat on the market for so long. Buyers begin to think that there is an issue with the home when in fact there isnâ€™t; the home was simply over priced in the beginning.

What Happens When You Price Your Home Too Low
     
The same goes for pricing your home too low; youâ€™re leaving money on the table you obviously want to avoid that. We stress pricing a home competitively and properly so the market reacts with foot traffic in your house. This also brings more offers in a timely manner; the more offers you have, the better you have to choose from.
     
 If you have any questions or want to know what your home is worth, give me a call at (540) 632-1199 or email me at Damon@DamonGettier.com.
